name: Floppydisk
description: The tricky thing when it comes to low ABV drinks is that the end result doesn’t always give that same feeling of a proper mixed drink. They can easily lack complexity and fall flat. On imbibes website they state this drink is “half the booze and double the flavor” which describes this drink perfectly.

ingredients.name: Cynar
ingredients.description: Bitter apéritif of the amaro variety. It is made from 13 herbs and plants, predominant among which is the artichoke (Cynara scolymus), from which the drink derives its name.

ingredients.name: Dry Curaçao
ingredients.description: Dry Curaçao is a type of orange-flavored liqueur that originated on the Caribbean island of Curaçao. Dry Curaçao is made from the peels of bitter oranges, and it is characterized by its dry and less sweet profile compared to regular Curaçao. It is often used as a premium orange liqueur in cocktails, imparting a bright citrus flavor without the added sweetness. Dry Curaçao is a versatile ingredient and is commonly featured in classic and modern mixology, contributing to a variety of cocktails.

ingredients.name: Mezcal
ingredients.description:
Mezcal is a distilled alcoholic beverage that originates from Mexico, known for its distinctive smoky flavor. It is made from the agave plant, primarily the species Agave espadin, although other agave varieties can be used. The production of mezcal involves roasting the agave hearts (piñas) in underground pits, which imparts a smoky character to the final product. After roasting, the agave is crushed, fermented, and then distilled, resulting in a spirit with a wide range of flavors, including earthy, fruity, and herbal notes.

The traditional production methods involve cooking the agave in earthen pits lined with lava rocks and filled with wood and charcoal. This underground roasting process gives mezcal its distinctive smoky taste.

Mezcal is produced in specific regions of Mexico, with Oaxaca being a particularly renowned area for its high-quality mezcals. The production of mezcal is regulated, and the spirit has a Denomination of Origin (DO) to ensure authenticity and quality.

Unlike some other agave spirits, such as tequila, which is made from Blue Agave, mezcal can be produced from a variety of agave types, contributing to the spirit's diversity.

Mezcal is deeply rooted in Mexican culture and has gained international recognition for its artisanal production methods and diverse flavor profile.

ingredients.name: Club soda
ingredients.description:
Club soda is a manufactured form of carbonated water, commonly used as a drink mixer. Also known as soda, siphon soda water, soda water, siphon soda, and siphon water.

Soda water is artificially or naturally carbonated water, to which mineral salts have been added. The product without the salts is termed "seltzer" or "seltzer water."

Carbonated water with added minerals—commonly sodium bicarbonate or salt—club soda was designed to approximate mineral water, which is often naturally fizzy, but can carry a hefty price tag. English chemist Joseph Priestly invented the process of carbonation in 1767, when he realized that the carbon dioxide produced during the fermentation of beer could be infused into water. Soon after, Jacob Schweppe, a Swiss watchmaker, figured out how to manufacture carbonated water (which has no added minerals) and club soda. These products would become the cornerstone of the Schweppes Company, which is still in existence today. The added salt or sodium bicarbonate helps to mitigate the sour flavors from the carbonic acid, a byproduct of carbon dioxide.
